conclusion: Understanding the problem involves a glass hemisphere with radius R and parallel light hitting it perpendicularly.
Goal is to find the maximum distance d from the optical axis for which incident rays can emerge without total internal reflection.
Refractive index of the glass is 1.5.
Light is incident perpendicular to the base, entering the glass without bending.
Light travels towards the curved surface of the hemisphere.
Optical axis is line OO', perpendicular to the base of the hemisphere.
Distance d represents how far off-center the ray is incident on the base.
Find maximum d such that the ray refracts out of the curved surface rather than reflecting back.
Critical angle for total internal reflection is needed.
Calculate critical angle θ_c using sin θ_c = 1/n.
θ_c ≈ arcsin(0.6667) ≈ 41.8 degrees.
Ray inside glass approaching the interface at angle > θ_c will undergo total internal reflection.
Consider ray incident at edge of total internal reflection region, approaching curved surface at θ_c.
Ray enters base at distance d from optical axis and travels straight to curved surface.
Normal to curved surface at any point is along the radius of the hemisphere.
Find relationship between d and angle of incidence at curved surface.
Consider triangle formed by O, point of entry on base, and point of exit on curved surface.
Point of entry is P, distance d from O, ray travels to curved surface hitting at Q.
Point Q lies on circumference of hemisphere, OQ = R.
Angle of incidence at Q is angle between ray PQ and normal OQ.
Find maximum d such that angle θ ≤ θ_c.
